JournalInfo.JournalSubTitle: Zeitschrift für Rohstoffe, Geotechnik, Metallurgie, Werkstoffe, Maschinen- und Anlagentechnik

ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Effects of Low Frequency Alternating Currents on the Electro-Slag Remelting Process
Einfluss der Frequenz auf das Umschmelzverhalten beim ESU-Prozess

Affiliation.OrgName: Univ. of Appl. Sciences Upper Austria, FH-OÖ-F&E-GmbH

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: In this paper the effects of a frequency variation between 1 and 4.5 Hz on the remelting behaviour and the distribution of non-metallic inclusion during electro-slag remelting of a hot-work tool steel in an open laboratory ESR plant are presented. The investigations include the determination of the energy consumption and of electrical effects such as polarisation and changes in the chemical compositions. Furthermore, the composition of the non-metallic inclusions was detected by automated SEM-EDS analysis. Frequency variations in this specific range have a tremendous effect on polarisation effects and the energy consumption. While there is a slight reduction of the oxygen content at 4.5 Hz, significant oxidation takes place at lower frequencies. As a consequence, the Si content of the steel is reduced and the amount of SiO2 in the slag increases. An almost complete removal of sulfides was detected in all experiments. The amounts of oxides and oxisulfides are significantly affected by the frequency. The oxides decrease strongly with rising frequency, which is in good correlation with the oxygen content. At the same time, the amount of oxisulfides is rising. The composition of the non-metallic inclusions depends also on the frequency applied. Starting with Al2O3-rich oxides at 1 Hz, the composition shifts towards a higher MgO content (spinel type) and CaO-rich oxides at higher frequency.

Abstract.Heading: Zusammenfassung
Abstract.Para: Diese Arbeit beschäftigt sich mit dem Einfluss der Frequenz im Bereich von 1 bis 4,5 Hz auf das Umschmelzverhalten und die Verteilung der Nichtmetallischen Einschlüsse (NME) beim ESU-Prozess. Die Arbeiten wurden mit einem Warmarbeitsstahl an einer offenen Versuchs-ESU-Anlage durchgeführt. Die Untersuchungen umfassen die Auswertung des Energieverbrauchs und von elektrischen Polarisationseffekte, wie die Veränderungen der chemischen Zusammensetzung von Block und Schlacke. Zusätzlich wurde mittels automatisierter Elektronenmikroskopie die Zusammensetzung der NME ermittelt. Änderungen der elektrischen Frequenz zeigen im untersuchten Bereich starke Auswirkungen auf Polarisationseffekte sowie den Energieverbrauch. Während bei 4,5 Hz der Sauerstoffgehalt leicht abnimmt, kommt es bei niedrigeren Frequenzen zu einer deutlichen Oxidation. Im Gegenzug reduziert sich bei niedrigen Frequenzen der Si-Gehalt im Stahl und es steigt der SiO2-Gehalt in der Schlacke. Während die Sulfide bei allen Frequenzen nahezu vollständig entfernt wurden zeigt sich ein deutlicher Effekt der Frequenz auf die Ausbildung von Oxiden und Oxisulfiden. Die Oxide werden mit steigender Frequenz deutlich verringert, im Gegenzug steigt die Menge an Oxisulfiden an. Die Zusammensetzung der NME ist ebenfalls von der Frequenz abhängig. Ausgehend von Al2O3-reichen Oxiden bei 1 Hz, kommt es mit steigender Frequenz zu einer deutliche MgO-Zunahme (v. a. Spinelle) und zu Einschlüssen mit höheren CaO-Gehalten.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Electro-slag remelting (ESR) is usually performed in plants using electric currents with frequencies of 50 or 60 Hz. One disadvantage of such electric power supply is its inductive reactive power. Therefore low-frequency concepts were proposed (e.g. [1]), where it has been shown that such power supply has no negative effects on the metallurgical results. Recent investigation on laboratory scale plants with low frequency ESR [2–4] have demonstrated that lower frequencies can lead to higher oxygen contents in the ingot and increased content of non-metallic inclusions.

Low-frequency ESR shows typical electrochemical reactions as they are known from DC power supplies [2–8]. Thereby it has to be taken into consideration that electrochemical reactions or polarisation effects are highly affected by the current density and, therefore, by the size of the remelting unit [7, 9, 10]. Practically no electrochemical reactions take place at large plants. At medium size plants, such reactions occur only at the electrode. Small ESR units (according to [10] at mould diameters of < 150 mm) may show polarisation and electrolysis at both sides of the liquid slag, at the electrode and at the metal pool.

To get a better understanding of these effects occurring during low frequency operation and to determine a critical frequency for an unaffected remelting procedure, the current investigation program was conducted.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: All experiments were performed on a laboratory scale open ESR plant with a mould diameter of 165 mm and both a low-frequency AC and a DC power supply with a maximum current of 5 kA and a maximum voltage of 100 V. A more detailed description of the plant can be found in [11].

Section2.Heading: Materials
Section2.Para: All experiments were performed using the hot-work tool steel ~H11/X37CrMoV5-1. The chemical composition of the steel (electrode) can be taken from Table 1. The electrodes had a diameter of 101.5 mm and a machined metallic bright surface.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Chemical composition of the electrode in [wt.%]

Section2.Para: The slag used was a commercial slag of the type “ESR 2015”. The nominal chemical composition is shown in Table 2.

Section2.Heading: Process Parameters
Section2.Para: The main parameters of the remelting experiments are summarised in Table 3. The parameters selected have a comparable melt rate, which required the increase of the current for remelting by 4.5 Hz. The voltage is the result of an almost constant immersion depth of about 1 cm.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Process parameters of the remelting experiments

tfooter.SimplePara: aCurrent and voltage value at the constant level (after overshooting) at the positive polarity

Section2.Para: Figure 1a shows a typical current-voltage time plot, determined at the output terminals of the rectifying circuit. As the alternating current is produced by two separate three phase rectifiers in anti-parallel connection, the typical current and voltage shape is rather rectangular. Between the negative and the positive current pulses, a dead time appears, which indicates the time to change in between the two rectifier bridges. After the change of the polarity, a voltage and current overshoot occurs. Figure 1b describes the determination of the polarisation from the current-voltage trace. While the current is regulated by the power source, the voltage is the result of the total resistance of the circuit, (mainly dominated by the slag). While there were no significant variations in the voltage during the positive part of the current flow, the voltage showed a typical rise during the negative part of the current flow, which was approaching a certain saturation level. The difference between the stable voltage in the positive loop and the voltage at the end of the negative loop was determined as polarisation ΔU. At the applied remelting currents, local arcing effects could be observed periodically at the boundary between the slag and the crucible during this phase of polarisation and saturation.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: a Typical results of a voltage and current plot and b determination of the polarisation

Section2.Heading: Material Investigations
Section2.Para: After remelting, the ingots were forged to a diameter of approximately 60 mm. Samples were taken successively for the chemical analysis of the ingot. Additionally, the slag was analysed after remelting. For the investigation of the non-metallic inclusions, an automated SEM-EDS system was used. This system detected not only the number and size distribution of the non-metallic inclusions on an area of 150 mm2, but also its chemical composition.

Section2.Heading: Specific Energy Consumption and Polarisation
Section2.Para: The effect of the frequency on the energy consumption during the stable phase of the remelting process can be seen in Fig. 2.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Specific energy consumption after remelting at different frequencies

Section2.Para: Except for the cooling energy at the bottom plate, which was similarly small in all experiments, and the energy losses in the rectifier, which also shows a rather constant level, there is a clear reduction in energy consumption as the frequency increases. This especially applies not only to the cooling energy of the crucible, which constantly drops, but also to the other energy losses, such as radiation or due to the resistance of the whole electrical circuit.

The polarisation effects in Fig. 3 correspond well with the energy consumption. At a frequency of 1 Hz, there is a strong polarisation effect reaching 12 V. Increasing the frequency to 3 Hz reduces the polarisation roughly by a factor of two. At 4.5 Hz, practically no polarisation (< 1 V) could be observed.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Effect of the frequency on polarisation effects

Section2.Para: Connected with the variation in the remelting behaviour, there was also a change in the shape of the electrode tip. While there was an almost flat electode at 3 and 4.5 Hz, the experiment with 1 Hz lead to a strong conical shape.

Section2.Heading: Chemical Compositions
Section2.Para: While there were practically no changes in the main alloying elements (carbon, chromium, molybdenum, and vanadium), changes in the content of silicon, aluminium, and oxygen could be observed clearly. The changes are summarized in Table 4. The loss of silicon is quite significant for the lower frequencies but is strongly reduced at 4.5 Hz. The amount of aluminium rises, independently of the frequency, to levels of almost three times the original content. The oxygen content increases sharply at the frequency of 1 Hz. At 3 Hz there is still a clear increase in oxygen in the ingot. The oxygen level could be slightly reduced only after remelting at 4.5 Hz.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Changes in the chemical composition between electrode and ingot [wt.%]

Section2.Para: The composition of the slag after remelting shows only one significant change (except dilution by silica), which is the silica content (Fig. 4). Starting with an initial level of about 1.5 wt.%, the SiO2-content rises more than four times after remelting at 1 and 3 Hz. At 4.5 Hz the SiO2-content rises significantly less, leading to an end-value of slightly above 4 wt.%.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Effect of the frequency on the SiO2-formation during remelting

Section2.Heading: Non-metallic Inclusions
Section2.Para: Figure 5 gives an overview of the content of different types on non-metallic inclusions (NMI) as well as the changes in oxygen content. Remelting at 1 Hz AC leads not only to a significant increase of oxygen but, correspondingly, also to a massive increase of oxides. With a strong reduction in oxisulfides (conglomerates) and sulfides, the total content increases from 28 to 32 NMI/mm2. At 3 Hz, the trend is similar but less pronounced. While the total content of NMI and oxygen is practically the same, there is still a clear increase in oxides and a strong drop in oxisulfides and sulfides. Raising the frequency to 4.5 Hz leads to a reduction of total NMI, which correlates to the slightly reduced oxygen content. The amount of oxides is much lower than at lower frequencies but higher than in the electrode, whereby oxisulfides are partly and sulfides are almost completely removed.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Number of non-metallic inclusions and oxygen content

Section2.Para: The change in the chemical composition of the oxidic NMI (oxides and oxidic part of the oxisulfides) is displayed in Fig. 6. The left column shows the position of all detected inclusions regarding their main constituents, Al2O3, CaO, and MgO as well as the size (ECD: equivalent cycle diameter) of each inclusion. In the right column, a density function describes the concentration of oxides. Areas in red indicate regions with a high number of inclusions. This is especially important for the many small inclusions with various Al2O3 and MgO content, which cannot be seen clearly in the left column.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Composition size and distribution of non-metallic inclusions

Section2.Para: In the electrode, the inclusions are scattered over a wide area, covering the whole range with Al2O3 contents larger than CaO content. While the largest inclusions can be found in the field of calcium-aluminates, with several inclusions larger than 10 µm, the majority is concentrated alongside the Al2O3-MgO axis, especially at high MgO-content.

Remelting generally leads to a strong reduction of high-MgO-containing inclusions and to the formation of new and fine inclusions in the area of calcium-aluminates and spinel-type oxides. What is most evident is the shift in the composition towards higher Al2O3 content at lower frequencies. At 1 Hz almost all oxides have Al2O3 content of 75 % or more. Furthermore, the amount of large inclusions is reduced by remelting.

Section2.Heading: Specific Energy Consumption and Polarisation
Section2.Para: Comparing the specific energy consumption of the 4.5 Hz experiment with data from larger ingots, 50 Hz operation and the same slag in [12] provides a good agreement. The significantly higher specific energy consumption at lower frequencies fits well to earlier results with lower melt rate and approaches the values of remelting with a DC (the electrode is the cathode) power supply [11]. This higher specific energy consumption for DC-operation is usually explained by polarisation effects [5, 6, 11] and correlates well with the increasing polarisation measured and observed with falling frequency in this experimental series.

Section2.Heading: Chemical Compositions
Section2.Para: Several chemical reactions take place between the atmosphere, the metal, and the slag during remelting. At the higher frequency of 4.5 Hz, the main reactions can be regarded as similar to a standard 50 Hz operation. According to [13–16] silicon is oxidised in an equilibrium-reaction with alumina (Reaction 1) and additionally by oxygen which is picked up from the atmosphere, partly due to a scaling of the electrode directly above the slag bath (Reaction 2). Both reactions lead to an increase of silica in the slag and Reaction 1 also to the observed increase of aluminium in the ingot.

Comparing the loss of silicon and the increase of aluminium in the steel indicates that at 4.5 Hz both reactions seem to be of importance. The reaction is further enhanced by the relatively high silicon content of the hot-work tool steel. As shown in [16] for the same conditions, the loss of silicon and the increase of aluminium can be significantly reduced by using a slag with a higher SiO2-content, which is in agreements with [1, 17].

At lower frequencies, Reaction 2 becomes dominant. The reason for this behaviour can be found in the prolonged period of time for the electrolytic Reaction 3, which, according to [2–4, 8], takes place at the anode during DC operation (especially in DC+ mode when the electrode is the anode).
The larger impact of the reaction at the electrode can be explained by the higher current density due to the smaller diameter compared to the metal pool of the ingot.

The increase in aluminium, which is almost similar at all three frequencies, may either solely depend on a constant contribution according to Reaction 1 or may be enhanced by an additional contributions due to Reaction 4, with Al2O3 being more readily available in the slag than SiO2.

The differences in the drop of the silicon content in the steel and the increase of silica in the slag is not fully consistent with each other, but roughly within the scatter range, which might be affected by the analytical method and the sampling. The content of SiO2 for 1 Hz operation (6.7 wt.%) is also in good agreement with previous experiments described in [3, 4]. Nevertheless it indicates that, once polarisation effects and the corresponding electrolytic reactions take place, there is a significant impact on the ingot and the slag composition.

Section2.Heading: Non-metallic Inclusions
Section2.Para: At low frequencies, Reaction 3 has a major impact not only on the loss in silicon and on the rise in the oxygen content but also on the amount of non-metallic inclusions. At 4.5 Hz a critical frequency seems to be reached, where no more electrolytic reactions occur and the oxygen content is slightly reduced. The general effect of the frequency is in good agreement with [2], but, in contrast to these results, an increase in oxygen was reported even for frequencies of up to 50 Hz. This different behaviour can, at least partly, be explained by the different sizes of the remelting equipment and different current densities. The shift from oxisulfides (usually mixtures/close conglomerates of oxides and sulfides) to oxides may be explained by the strong removal of sulfides, which leaves pure oxides behind. Based on Reaction 3 and in accordance with [2–4], higher oxygen contents lead to the formation of more oxides.

The composition of the non-metallic inclusions in the field of higher-Al containing Al-Ca-Mg oxides is in good agreement with other published results on hot-work tool steels for 50 Hz as well as for low-frequency operation [3, 4, 18, 19]. A reduction, and even elimination, of high MgO containing oxides, as reported in [3, 20], could be found in all experiments, but is more pronounced at lower frequencies. The oxides in the ingot are therefore newly formed during solidification, which is in good correlation with [21]. This shift towards higher alumina contents at rising oxygen levels in the steel fits to earlier results with low-frequency AC and DC experiments, where the number of alumina-type inclusions was highest for DC+ operation [3, 4]

Section1.Heading: Summary and Conclusions
Section1.Para: Similar to electro-slag remelting with a DC power supply, also at low frequency AC electrical current, the effect of polarisation and electrochemical reactions depend on the current density and thereby on the size of the plant. The results achieved can therefore be regarded representative of small to medium size plants, where electrochemical reactions take place at the electrode. For such conditions the following conclusions can be drawn:

ItemContent.Para: Lower frequencies enhance the occurrence of polarisation effects, provided that a sufficient current density is available. Under the conditions investigated, the limit for such phenomena is in the range of 4.5 Hz.
With a frequency of 4.5 Hz, similar results regarding energy consumption, chemical composition, and non-metallic inclusions were obtained as for industrial plants with a frequency of 50 Hz.
Polarisation effects at low-frequency (< 4 Hz) operation lead to a significant increase in energy consumption.

While there is a loss of silicon and a gain in aluminium due to equilibrium conditions for all investigated frequencies, the loss of silicon by oxidation is significantly enhanced when electrolytic reactions due to low frequencies (< 4 Hz) take place.
The electrolytic absorption of oxygen at low frequencies increases the total amount of oxidic non-metallic inclusions in the steels and changes its composition to higher alumina contents.
